titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Louis Kline Papers
titlestmt.author: by Lisa Conathan and Jennifer Meehan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection documents George L. Kline's work as a translator for Joseph Brodsky and related activities, including the translation of other Russian prose and poetry and scholarship on Russian literature. Included are correspondence, drafts of Brodsky's poems and Kline's English translations, sound recordings of Brodsky, and photographs of Brodsky and others. Other than Brodsky, correspondents include W. H. Auden, Nina Berberova, Leonid Chertkov, Anthony Hecht, Lev Losev, Faith Wizgell and Igor Efimov. Manuscripts include signed typescripts of several of Brodsky's poems and typescript poems of Evgenii Rein inscribed to Joseph Brodsky. Among the sound recordings is a recording of Brodsky reciting his poems in 1968 in his Leningrad apartment, recorded by George Kline.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: The George Louis Kline Papers were acquired to complement the Joseph Brodsky Papers. The Beinecke Library acquired papers that document Kline's translations of Brodsky's poetry and of other Russian prose and poetry. Papers that document Kline's lengthy career as a professor at Bryn Mawr College and his scholarship in other domains were not acquired.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Access to original audiovisual recordings is restricted. Researchers should consult the Beinecke Library Access Services department for policies and procedures for the creation of reference copies, if none exist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The George Louis Kline Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George Louis Kline Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, and competing priorities. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing at the time of acquisition, including rehousing and minimal organization. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.

bioghist.head: George Louis Kline (b. 1921)
bioghist.p: George L. Kline, professor emeritus at Bryn Mawr College, is a scholar of philosophy and literature and translates Russian prose and poetry. His translations include the poetry of Joseph Brodsky, Marina Tsvetaeva and Anna Akhmatova.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents George L. Kline's work as a translator for Joseph Brodsky and related activities, including the translation of other Russian prose and poetry and scholarship on Russian literature. Included are correspondence, drafts of Brodsky's poems and Kline's English translations, sound recordings of Brodsky, and photographs of Brodsky and others. Other than Brodsky, correspondents include W. H. Auden, Nina Berberova, Leonid Chertkov, Anthony Hecht, Lev Losev, Faith Wigzell and Igor Efimov. Manuscripts include signed typescripts of several of Brodsky's poems and typescript poems of Evgenii Rein inscribed to Joseph Brodsky. Among the sound recordings is a recording of Brodsky reciting his poems in 1968 in his Leningrad apartment, recorded by George Kline.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1972-2000. II. Writings, circa 1965-2000. III. Other Papers, circa 1978-1996.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Correspondence with Joseph Brodsky, Correspondence about Joseph Brodsky, and Other Correspondence.

did.unittitle: Incoming letters and copies of outgoing letters

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by correspondent. One folder of correspondence with publishers is filed at the end of the alphabetic listing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes typescripts (originals and photocopies) of Joseph Brodsky's poetry in Russian, many annotated by Kline, drafts of Kline's translations, some corrected by Kline and/or Brodsky, and a holograph manuscript of an occasional poem Brodsky wrote for Kline ("Fast-shrift (sic) for George L. Kline"). Also present is a proof of Ostanovka v Pustyne, heavily corrected by Brodsky. Among George Kline's writings and translations are drafts of English translations of poetry by Anna Akhmatova, Boris Pasternak, and Marina Tsvetaeva, among others. Also present are two folders of clean copies of Kline's published writings, 1949-1970.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Joseph Brodsky Writings, George L. Kline Writings, and Other Writings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files contain drafts of translations, essays, lectures and correspondence related to Kline's translations of Russian poetry and literary analyses.

Kline essays and other writings on Brodsky

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.p: Typescripts of poems by Evgenii Rein, Vladimir Ufliand, Leonid Chertkov, Dmitri Bobyshev and ____ Krasovedskii.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

did.unittitle: Reviews of Brodsky and of Kline's translations
Photographs of Joseph Brodsky and George Kline

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Twelve audiocassettes, including a 1968 recording of Brodsky reciting his poetry in his Leningrad apartment.
